case_name: Sitabai and Suresh Chandra v. Ramchandra

facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 856 of 1966 is an appeal by special leave.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal by special leave from the judgment and decree dated September 7, 1965 of the Madhya Pradesh High Court, Indore Bench in Second Appeal No. 275 of 1962.

facts.text: Madhya Pradesh High Court, Indore Bench delivered judgment and decree dated September 7, 1965 in Second Appeal No. 275 of 1962.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal by special leave from the judgment and decree dated September 7, 1965 of the Madhya Pradesh High Court, Indore Bench in Second Appeal No. 275 of 1962.

facts.text: Dulichand and Bhagirath were brothers.

anchor.surface_text: Dulichand and Bhagirath were brothers and the properties concerned are, according to the written statement of the defendant himself, ancestral.

facts.text: The properties concerned are ancestral according to the written statement of the defendant.

anchor.surface_text: Dulichand and Bhagirath were brothers and the properties concerned are, according to the written statement of the defendant himself, ancestral.

facts.text: Plaintiff Sitabai is the widow of Bhagirath.

anchor.surface_text: Plaintiff Sitabai is the widow of Bhagirath, who predeceased Dulichand, his elder brother sometime in 1930.

facts.text: Bhagirath predeceased Dulichand sometime in 1930.

anchor.surface_text: Plaintiff Sitabai is the widow of Bhagirath, who predeceased Dulichand, his elder brother sometime in 1930.

facts.text: After Bhagirath died, plaintiff Sitabai was living with Dulichand as a result of which connection an illegitimate child defendant Ramchandra was born in 1935.

anchor.surface_text: It is the admitted case of both the parties that after Bhagirath died, the plaintiff Sitabai was living with Dulichand as a result of which connection an illegitimate child defendant Ramchandra was born in 1935.

facts.text: Dulichand died on March 13, 1958.

anchor.surface_text: Dulichand died on March 13, 1958. Sometime before his death Sitabai adopted plaintiff number 2 Suresh Chandra and an adoption deed was executed on March 4, 1958.

facts.text: Sitabai adopted plaintiff number 2 Suresh Chandra and an adoption deed was executed on March 4, 1958.

anchor.surface_text: Dulichand died on March 13, 1958. Sometime before his death Sitabai adopted plaintiff number 2 Suresh Chandra and an adoption deed was executed on March 4, 1958.

facts.text: After the death of Dulichand Ramchandra took possession of the joint family properties.

anchor.surface_text: After the death of Dulichand Ramchandra took possession of the joint family properties. The plaintiff therefore brought the present suit for ejectment of the defendant Ramchandra,

facts.text: Plaintiffs brought suit for ejectment of defendant Ramchandra from the disputed properties.

anchor.surface_text: After the death of Dulichand Ramchandra took possession of the joint family properties. The plaintiff therefore brought the present suit for ejectment of the defendant Ramchandra, the illegitimate son of Dulichand from the disputed properties.

facts.text: Defendant contested suit on ground that Dulichand surrendered lands to Jagirdar who made resettlement with defendant.

anchor.surface_text: The suit was contested by the defendant on the ground that Dulichand had in his lifetime surrendered the lands to the Jagirdar who made resettlement of the same with the defendant.

facts.text: Defendant contended that Dulichand executed a will before death making bequest of house to him.

anchor.surface_text: As regards the house the contention of the defendant was that Dulichand had executed a will before his death making a bequest of his house entirely to him.

facts.text: Trial court decided all issues in favour of plaintiff and granted decree for possession of land and house.

anchor.surface_text: The trial court decided all the issues in favour of the plaintiff and granted the plaintiffs a decree for possession with regard to the land and the house.

facts.text: District Judge modified decree holding will valid for half share in house.

anchor.surface_text: The defendant took the matter in appeal to the District Judge who modified the decree. The District Judge took the view that the will executed by Dulichand was valid so far as half of his share in the house was concerned

facts.text: Madhya Pradesh High Court in second appeal reversed lower courts and dismissed suit.

anchor.surface_text: The defendant preferred a second appeal before the Madhya Pradesh High Court which reversed the decree of the lower courts and held that the plaintiff was not entitled to any relief and the suit should be dismissed in its entirety.

facts.text: Properties consisted of agricultural land and a house jointly held by Bhagirath and Dulichand.

anchor.surface_text: It is the admitted case of both the parties that the properties consisted of agricultural land and a house jointly held by Bhagirath and Dulichand.

facts.text: After death of Bhagirath, Dulichand became sole surviving coparcener of joint family.

anchor.surface_text: After the death of Bhagirath, Dulichand became the sole surviving coparcener of the joint family.

facts.text: Additional District Judge dated April 21, 1962 in First Appeal No. 26 of 1961.

anchor.surface_text: the judgment and decree of the Additional District Judge, indore dated April 21, 1962 in First Appeal No. 26 of 1961 should be restored.

facts.text: Supreme Court holds judgment of High Court should be set aside and Additional District Judge decree restored.

anchor.surface_text: For the reasons already given we hold that the judgment and decree of the High Court of Madhya Pradesh dated September 7, 1965 in Second Appeal No. 275 of 1962 should be set aside and the judgment and decree of the Additional District Judge, indore dated April 21, 1962 in First Appeal No. 26 of 1961 should be restored.
Appeal by special leave from the judgment and decree dated September 7, 1965 of the Madhya Pradesh High Court, Indore Bench in Second Appeal No. 275 of 1962.

holdings.text: The High Court was not right in holding that plaintiff number 2 Suresh Chandra at the time of his adoption by plaintiff number 1 did not become a coparcener of Dulichand in the joint family properties.

anchor.surface_text: The first question to be considered in this appeal is whether the High Court was right in holding that plaintiff number 2 Suresh Chandra at the time of his adoption by plaintiff number 1 did number become a companyarcener of Dulichand in the joint family properties.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Joint family continues with sole coparcener and widow entitled to maintenance; property retains coparcenary character per Gowli Buddanna and Arunachalam precedents.

holdings.text: After the death of Bhagirath the joint family property continued to retain its character in the hands of Dulichand as the widow of Bhagirath was still alive and continued to enjoy the right of maintenance out of the joint family properties.

anchor.surface_text: after the death of Bhagirath the joint family property continued to retain its character in the hands of Dulichand as the widow of Bhagirath was still alive and continued to enjoy the right of maintenance out of the joint family properties.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Applying Gowli Buddanna and Attorney General of Ceylon v. A.R. Arunachalam Chettiar: joint family property does not cease to be joint merely due to single coparcener when widow has maintenance right.

holdings.text: Suresh Chandra, plaintiff number 2, when he was adopted by Bhagirath's widow became a coparcener of Dulichand in the Hindu joint family properties.

anchor.surface_text: The question next arises whether Suresh Chandra, plaintiff number 2, when he was adopted by Bhagiraths widow became a companyarcener of Dulichand in the Hindu joint family properties.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Adoption by widow under HAMA makes adopted son son of both widow and deceased husband, entering joint family as coparcener with husband's brother.

holdings.text: The true effect and interpretation of ss. 11 and 12 of Act No. 78 of 1956 is that when either of the spouses adopts a child, all the ties of the child in the family of his or her birth become completely severed and these are all replaced by those created by the adoption in the adoptive family; the result of adoption by either spouse is that the adoptive child becomes the child of both the spouses.

anchor.surface_text: Section 12 enacts An adopted child shall be deemed to be the child of his or her adoptive father or mother for all purposes with effect from the date of the adoption

holdings.reasoning_summary: Textual reading of ss.11(vi),12,14 HAMA: severance of birth ties, creation of adoptive ties; widow's adoption ties child to deceased husband's family; supported by Bombay HC precedent.

holdings.text: Plaintiff number 2 Suresh Chandra, when he was adopted by Bhagirath's widow, became the adopted son of both the widow and her deceased husband Bhagirath and, therefore, became a coparcener with Dulichand in the joint family properties.

anchor.surface_text: This view is borne out by the decision of the Bombay High Court in Arukushi Narayan v. Janabai Sama Sawat 1 . It follows that in the present case plaintiff number 2 Suresh Chandra, when he was adopted by Bhagiraths widow, became the adopted son of both the widow and her deceased husband Bhagirath and, therefore, became a companyarcener with Dulichand in the joint family properties.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Direct application: adoption integrates into widow's family, making coparcener with uncle Dulichand.

holdings.text: The rights of the Inamdar's tenants were heritable under the Madhya Bharat Land Revenue and Tenancy Act, 1950; heritability of ordinary tenancies governed by personal law of tenants absent special statutory provision.

anchor.surface_text: in the absence of any special statutory provision, the heritability of ordinary tenancies must be governed by the personal law of the tenants companycerned.

holdings.reasoning_summary: No bar in Act; ss.86,87 contemplate heritability and mutation on death; personal law (Hindu) applies.

holdings.text: We accordingly reject the argument of the respondent that the rights of Dulichand were not heritable.

anchor.surface_text: We accordingly reject the argument of the respondent that the rights of Dulichand were number heritable.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Act silent on ordinary tenants; s.86 applies to all tenants including on death; personal law governs.

holdings.text: The jurisdiction of the Civil Court was not barred by the provisions of the Madhya Bharat Land Revenue Administration and Ryotwari Land Revenue and Tenancy Act, 1950.

anchor.surface_text: It is also urged on behalf of the respondent that the jurisdiction of the Civil Court was barred by the provisions of the Madhya Bharat Land Revenue Administration and Ryotwari Land Revenue and Tenancy Act, 1950  Act number 66 of 1950 .

holdings.reasoning_summary: Issue decided against respondent by trial and first appellate courts; not challenged in High Court; not raisable now.

holdings.text: The judgment and decree of the High Court of Madhya Pradesh dated September 7, 1965 in Second Appeal No. 275 of 1962 should be set aside and the judgment and decree of the Additional District Judge, Indore dated April 21, 1962 in First Appeal No. 26 of 1961 should be restored.

anchor.surface_text: For the reasons already given we hold that the judgment and decree of the High Court of Madhya Pradesh dated September 7, 1965 in Second Appeal No. 275 of 1962 should be set aside and the judgment and decree of the Additional District Judge, indore dated April 21, 1962 in First Appeal No. 26 of 1961 should be restored.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Based on resolutions of coparcenary status, adoption effect, heritability, and jurisdiction.

precedents.citation: Gowli Buddanna v. Commissioner of Income-tax, Mysore 1

anchor.surface_text: It has been pointed out in Gowli Buddanna v. Commissioner of Income-tax, Mysore 1  that under the Hindu system of law a joint family may companysist of a single male member and widows of deceased male members and that the property of a joint family did number cease to belong to a joint family merely because the family is represented by a single companyarcener who possesses rights which an absolute owner of property may possess. In that case, one Buddappa, his wife, his two unmarried daughters and his unmarried son, Buddanna, were members of a Hindu undivided family.

precedents.case_name: Gowli Buddanna v. Commissioner of Income-tax, Mysore
precedents.cited_proposition: under the Hindu system of law a joint family may consist of a single male member and widows of deceased male members and that the property of a joint family did not cease to belong to a joint family merely because the family is represented by a single coparcener who possesses rights which an absolute owner of property may possess
precedents.cited_holding: since the property which came into the hands of Buddanna as the sole surviving coparcener was originally joint family property, it did not cease to belong to the joint family and income from it was assessable in the hands of Buddanna as income of the Hindu Undivided Family

precedents.citation: Attorney General of Ceylon v.A.R. Arunachalam Chettiar 2

anchor.surface_text: As a pointed out by the Judicial Committee in Attorney General of Ceylon v.A.R. Arunachalam Chettiar 2  it is only by analysing  1  60 I.T.R. 293  S.C. .  2  1957 A.C. 540. the nature of the rights of the members of the undivided family, both those in being and those yet to be born, that it can be determined whether the family property can properly be described as joint property of the undivided family. In that case one Arunachalam Chettiar and his son constituted a joint family governed by the Mitakshara school of Hindu law.

precedents.case_name: Attorney General of Ceylon v. A.R. Arunachalam Chettiar
precedents.cited_proposition: it is only by analysing the nature of the rights of the members of the undivided family, both those in being and those yet to be born, that it can be determined whether the family property can properly be described as joint property of the undivided family; property in hands of sole surviving coparcener remains joint family property
precedents.cited_holding: Arunachalam was at his death a member of the Hindu undivided family... the property in the hands of Arunachalam as a single coparcener was the property of the Hindu undivided family; though it may be correct to speak of him as the owner, yet it is still correct to describe that which he owns as the joint family property

precedents.citation: Arukushi Narayan v. Janabai Sama Sawat 1

anchor.surface_text: This view is borne out by the decision of the Bombay High Court in Arukushi Narayan v. Janabai Sama Sawat 1 . It follows that in the present case plaintiff number 2 Suresh Chandra, when he was adopted by Bhagiraths widow, became the adopted son of both the widow and her deceased husband Bhagirath and, therefore, became a coparcener with Dulichand in the joint family properties.

precedents.case_name: Arukushi Narayan v. Janabai Sama Sawat
precedents.cited_proposition: effect of adoption under the Hindu Adoptions and Maintenance Act, 1956 that adopted child by widow becomes child of both widow and her deceased husband

anchor.surface_text: This view is borne out by the decision of the Bombay High Court in Arukushi Narayan v. Janabai Sama Sawat 1 . It follows that in the present case plaintiff number 2 Suresh Chandra, when he was adopted by Bhagiraths widow, became the adopted son of both the widow and her deceased husband Bhagirath and, therefore, became a companyarcener with Dulichand in the joint family properties.

For the reasons already given we hold that the judgment and decree of the High Court of Madhya Pradesh dated September 7, 1965 in Second Appeal number 275 of 1962 should be set aside and the judgment and decree of the Additional District Judge, indore
